ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Biased Random Hill Walking

Hi Colin,

I think CMA-ES and EDAs are doing something like this, although =
they are also modeling correlations between connections so they can account=
 for epistasis. I don=E2=80=99t understand them very well, but that is my h=
igh-level picture of what they do. If anyone knows them better, please chim=
e in!


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor, Computer Science
Dir=
ector, Evolving Artificial Intelligence Lab <http://evolvingai.org/>
Univer=
sity of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com

> On May 10, 2015, at 3:5=
4 PM, Colin Green colin.green1@... [neat] <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrot=
e:
> 
> Thinking some more about how RMSProp compares to neuro-evolution, i=
.e.
> random hill walking...
> 
> Question: Are there ways we could modify =
a random hill walking
> approach to be more like RMSProp?
> 
> At first it =
seems not since RMSProp is a form of gradient descent and
> we don't calcul=
ate gradients in the neuro-evolution world, that's kind
> of the whole poin=
t. It's the key thing that distinguishes us from the
> gradient descent 'wo=
rld'.
> 
> OK let's back up. RMSProp works because it uses a recent history=
 of
> gradients alongside the current gradient in order to choose a better
=
> step size. By step size I mean how far we should move and in what
> direc=
tion, i.e. should we increase or decrease this connection weight,
> and by =
how much?
> 
> Side note: RMSProp doesn't store an actual history of gradie=
nt for
> each variable, that would take up too much RAM. Instead each varia=
ble
> has it's own 'moving average', that works a bit like this:
> 
> movin=
g_average(t) =3D (moving_average(t-1) + gradient(t)) / 2
> 
> (That's not t=
he actual expression in RMSProp, but hopefully it gives
> you the general i=
dea.)
> 
> Ignoring for the moment what RMSProp actually does with this mov=
ing
> average, could we use something similar in NEAT? How would that work?=

> 
> One possible scheme works like this. When we mutate a connection
> we=
ight, instead of the delta being random (whether that be uniform or
> gauss=
ian), maybe it could be a biased random delta, where the bias is
> based on=
 a recent history of deltas for that weight.
> 
> The recent history in thi=
s case would be the delta applied to this
> weight in it's ancestors, that =
is, it's parent, grandparent, etc. (I'm
> assuming asexual repro right now =
to keep it simple and make this
> work).
> 
> Say the If the last N weight =
changes were all positive (increasing
> weight); that implies the offspring=
 from those N previous spawnings
> were good enough to still be in the popu=
lation, which in turn implies
> that increasing the weight by about the sam=
e amount again might be a
> good idea. We don't want to use the average del=
ta directly because we
> still wan't randomness, but we could bias that ran=
domness such that a
> weight increase is more likely (e.g. change the mode/=
mean of a
> Gaussian RNG, or skew it so it's asymmetrical, whatever).
> 
> =
Problem: In sexual repro we have two histories (one per parent). But
> mayb=
e we just take the average over the combined histories, so long as
> we can=
 match up the weights (which of course we can in NEAT).
> 
> In summary; In=
 NEAT we don't ever calc a gradient or have any idea of
> the gradients we =
are following via random walk, but gradients are
> there, and the path desc=
ribed by a random walk gives us some
> information about the landscape and =
the likely gradient at the current
> location, so maybe we can use that inf=
ormation to inform the random
> walk about better directions to explore.
> =

> Colin
> 


--Apple-Mail=_937768E5-6BD2-420F-BAAB-C897E412C650

<div class=3D"">On May 10, 2015, at 3:54 PM, Colin Green <a href=3D"mailto:=

=









 
<div style=3D"background-color: #fff;" class=3D"">
<span style=
=3D"display:none" class=3D""> </span>



    <div id=3D"ygrp-text" cla=
ss=3D""><p class=3D"">Thinking some more about how RMSProp compares to neur=
o-evolution, i.e.<br class=3D"">
random hill walking...<br class=3D"">
<br =
class=3D"">
Question: Are there ways we could modify a random hill walking<=
br class=3D"">
approach to be more like RMSProp?<br class=3D"">
<br class=
=3D"">
At first it seems not since RMSProp is a form of gradient descent an=
d<br class=3D"">
we don't calculate gradients in the neuro-evolution world,=
 that's kind<br class=3D"">
of the whole point. It's the key thing that dis=
tinguishes us from the<br class=3D"">
gradient descent 'world'.<br class=3D=
"">
<br class=3D"">
OK let's back up. RMSProp works because it uses a recen=
t history of<br class=3D"">
gradients alongside the current gradient in ord=
er to choose a better<br class=3D"">
step size. By step size I mean how far=
 we should move and in what<br class=3D"">
direction, i.e. should we increa=
se or decrease this connection weight,<br class=3D"">
and by how much?<br c=
lass=3D"">
<br class=3D"">
Side note: RMSProp doesn't store an actual histo=
ry of gradient for<br class=3D"">
each variable, that would take up too muc=
h RAM. Instead each variable<br class=3D"">
has it's own 'moving average', =
that works a bit like this:<br class=3D"">
<br class=3D"">
moving_average(t=
) =3D (moving_average(t-1) + gradient(t)) / 2<br class=3D"">
<br class=3D""=
>
(That's not the actual expression in RMSProp, but hopefully it gives<br c=
lass=3D"">
you the general idea.)<br class=3D"">
<br class=3D"">
Ignoring f=
or the moment what RMSProp actually does with this moving<br class=3D"">
av=
erage, could we use something similar in NEAT? How would that work?<br clas=
s=3D"">
<br class=3D"">
One possible scheme works like this. When we mutate=
 a connection<br class=3D"">
weight, instead of the delta being random (whe=
ther that be uniform or<br class=3D"">
gaussian), maybe it could be a biase=
d random delta, where the bias is<br class=3D"">
based on a recent history =
of deltas for that weight.<br class=3D"">
<br class=3D"">
The recent histor=
y in this case would be the delta applied to this<br class=3D"">
weight in =
it's ancestors, that is, it's parent, grandparent, etc. (I'm<br class=3D"">=

assuming asexual repro right now to keep it simple and make this<br class=
=3D"">
work).<br class=3D"">
<br class=3D"">
Say the If the last N weight c=
hanges were all positive (increasing<br class=3D"">
weight); that implies t=
he offspring from those N previous spawnings<br class=3D"">
were good enoug=
h to still be in the population, which in turn implies<br class=3D"">
that =
increasing the weight by about the same amount again might be a<br class=3D=
"">
good idea. We don't want to use the average delta directly because we<b=
r class=3D"">
still wan't randomness, but we could bias that randomness suc=
h that a<br class=3D"">
weight increase is more likely (e.g. change the mod=
e/mean of a<br class=3D"">
Gaussian RNG, or skew it so it's asymmetrical, w=
hatever).<br class=3D"">
<br class=3D"">
Problem: In sexual repro we have t=
wo histories (one per parent). But<br class=3D"">
maybe we just take the av=
erage over the combined histories, so long as<br class=3D"">
we can match u=
p the weights (which of course we can in NEAT).<br class=3D"">
<br class=3D=
"">
In summary; In NEAT we don't ever calc a gradient or have any idea of<b=
r class=3D"">
the gradients we are following via random walk, but gradients=
 are<br class=3D"">
there, and the path described by a random walk gives us=
 some<br class=3D"">
information about the landscape and the likely gradien=
t at the current<br class=3D"">
location, so maybe we can use that informat=
ion to inform the random<br class=3D"">
walk about better directions to exp=
lore.<br class=3D"">
<br class=3D"">
Colin<br class=3D"">
</p>

    </div>
=
